### Energy

Global Biodiversity Implications of Alternative Electrification Strategies Under the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (McManamay et al., 2021)

Biodiversity Footprint: Measured as species impacted per GWh

Biomass highest biodiversity impact. Despite its low contribution to the global energy mix, its low energy density requires vast land areas, often overlapping with biodiversity hotspots
Solar: cause intense land degradation, their high energy density means they require significantly less total area to meet electricity demands
Hydropower and Wind: These also exhibited high biodiversity footprints due to lower energy densities compared to fossil fuels and solar
Fossil Fuels: Generally had lower biodiversity footprints per GWh than many renewables, though their impacts on aquatic species remained notable

consolidating large-scale solar and wind development, rather than "dilute" or patchy deployment, could significantly lessen the burden on global biodiversity
